What to do when a person is not breathing
Help someone who is choking on food or object
How to stop heavy bleeding from wounds
First aid for thermal and chemical burns
Check if the person responds. Gently shake the shoulders and ask loudly: \"Are you okay?\" Look for breathing – chest movement, breathing sounds.
If the person does not respond and is not breathing, call 112 immediately. If someone is nearby, ask them for help.
Place your hands in the center of the chest. Press hard and fast (100–120 compressions per minute) to a depth of 5–6 cm.
After 30 compressions give 2 rescue breaths if trained. Tilt the head back, lift the chin and watch the chest rise.
Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until emergency services arrive or the person starts breathing.
Ask: \"Are you choking?\" If they cannot speak, cough or breathe, they need immediate help. Call 112 if severe.
Stand behind the person. Give 5 sharp blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of your hand.
If back blows don\'t work, perform 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver). Stand behind, place fist above navel, pull sharply inward and upward.
Press firmly on the wound with a clean cloth or bandage. Maintain constant pressure for at least 10 minutes.
If possible, raise the injured limb above heart level while maintaining pressure. This helps reduce blood flow to the wound.
Once bleeding slows, apply a firm bandage over the wound. Do not remove the first layer if blood soaks through – add more layers.
Hold the burned area under cool (not cold) running water for at least 10–20 minutes. Do not use ice or very cold water.
Carefully remove any jewelry, watches, or tight clothing near the burn before swelling starts. Do not remove clothing stuck to the burn.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-fluffy bandage or cling film. Do not apply butter, toothpaste, or other home remedies.
Do not move the injured limb. Immobilize it in the position found. Movement can cause more damage and pain.
Use padding (clothing, blankets) to support and cushion the injured area. Create a splint using rigid materials if trained.
Apply ice wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling. Call emergency services. Do not give food or water in case surgery is needed.
